turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: A private investigator... Youre not Austrian?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Should I be?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Whats a French private investigator doing here?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Can I get up now?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: No! What do you want here? How do you know me?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: As you know from speaking to Phil, your friend Leon has disappeared, Rhian. His family have hired me to find him.

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: ...Leons not here. How did you get here? Phil doesnt know where I live.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Well, I obviously do. And I also know that Leons not here, Rhian. But I thought that you might know where I should look for him.

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: You thought wrong. I havent seen Leon for months.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Havent you? Then why the worried messages on his answering machine, Rhian? Id have sworn you expect him to be in trouble.

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: You-youre wrong. I just called to ask if I could stay with him next time Im in London. Thats all.

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: What are you going to do now? Call the police?  Take him away? I must warn you hes terrified of men, so...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: We didnt quite make it as lovers... Leon is a good man, though...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Did Leon tell you why he didnt want the police involved, Rhian?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: He just said he had good reasons.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Good reasons?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Thats what he said. I tried to dissuade him... Told him I couldnt take on another child, that hed get into trouble... I mean, people who sell children... But he wasnt listening... I guess he finally found himself a crusade... His family think hes back on drugs, eh?  Huh... Leon did drugs. A lot of drugs. Went through his self-destruct phase, you know?  Things to come to terms with. Demons to fight... Some peoples minds are gloriously uncomplicated. Not Leons. He did beat the drug, though. He did.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: His mother would be pleased to hear that.

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Yeah... But he didnt beat the demons...  A quarter of all the shoes sold in Europe are made by or retailed through his parents leather empire. All started from a small shop in the East End of London and war reparation money for holocaust victims.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Im afraid I dont understand.

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Theyre German Jews. Came here before the war. They both lost all their families in extermination camps, but they themselves never went near one. The idea that his family wealth was started with money he believes should have gone to camp survivors has been haunting Leon. Its not guilt, more of a curse...  And then theres something about his parents being involved with Nazi hunters... But I think thats just one of Leons dark delusions...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Do you know Leons parents names?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Albert... Albert and Ethel. Why?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Who else knows about the boy?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: My sister... She lives in the next valley.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Is she on the phone?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Yes...You-youre not going to take Shiva away?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I cant think of a good reason for it - for now anyway. My number if anything happens. Whats your sisters number?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Oh, I... She just moved. Ive got her new... Its in my book in the kitchen. Wait... Thank you.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: And you better stop greeting strangers with a shotgun. If Leons Austrian was looking for you I reckon hed have found you before I did.

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Im sorry. Its just you dont look local...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: No sick people in the country, huh?... Just tell me one thing, Rhian. Leons story about the boy? You just took his word for it?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Hed come prepared. He had something besides Shiva... Sleeping Beauty. The Disney film...  Well, it looked like the Disney film. It was something else. I couldnt watch...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Whats the date?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: The nineteenth... How come you didnt know?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Ive been away.  Did Leon speak to you about his sister?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Er... Yes...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Did he ever refer to the hostility between them?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: He... Apparently the hostility was all hers. Leon didnt... It hurt him. They used to be close...  Their parents were in their forties when they were born, you see. And mostly away. They grew up in a Scottish mansion with old nannies and servants. He... Our world was so old and cold, we shone for one another, Leon used to say. His sister cut him off after she got married. He never understood why but thought it was because she had no children. Was bitter...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The money Leon left for the boy, was it cash?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Yes. Three thousand pounds. I still...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Did he mention anything about having an exhibition of his work?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You sure? What about before he turned up with the boy?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: ... No. In fact, Id seen him a couple of months earlier. He was quite depressed. His work wasnt getting anywhere. He said he was going to try something new, realism, London in the nineties - documentary stuff, you know...

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: He showed me a book with a picture of a couple caught kissing in a street...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Hows the boy doing?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Fine...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Good. You neednt worry about the Austrian anymore. Hes dead. Ill be in touch.

turns.speaker: OLD COWBOY
turns.text: And you aint neither one of those damned Mexicans who end up littering the landscape after getting ripped-off by their friendly cross- border guides, are you, mister?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: OLD COWBOY
turns.text: I didnt think so. The rags on their sorry backs are the only wordly possessions those wretched creatures are ever found with...  I dont wanna know who you are or how come you ended up roasting in Owl Canyon. But you might as well know Id have let you fry to a buzzard meal if not for this...

turns.speaker: OLD COWBOY
turns.text: Now, can you stand up?  Can you use your legs and stand up?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I... How long have I been here?

turns.speaker: OLD COWBOY
turns.text: Three days and thats three days too many.Come on. Get your ass up.

turns.speaker: OLD COWBOY
turns.text: Huh... I guess you aint quite ready for civilisation yet... Ill give you one more day, a meal, and then youre on your way.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Los Angeles?

turns.speaker: OLD COWBOY
turns.text: Los Angeles is 100 miles away.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Id appreciate it if I could use your phone.

turns.speaker: OLD COWBOY
turns.text: Im sure you would. But if I had one, I wouldnt let you near it. Now you tuck back in and rest until youre told otherwise.  And for what its worth, I wouldnt try anything that might be construed as unappreciative of my hospitality. Id sooner shoot you than have you upset me...

turns.speaker: OLD COWBOY
turns.text: Barstows 30 miles to the left. Los Angeles a hundred to the right. Wherever youre heading, I reckon somebodyll pick you up.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Huh... I suppose the idea of a one day trip to Los Angeles doesnt appeal to you...

turns.speaker: OLD COWBOY
turns.text: Is that where lawyers toil for an industry that turns serial killers into heroes who give thrills to young women who write erotic novels about psychopaths and rapists?  You go to your world, Ill stay in mine. So long, Mister.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Welcome to the club.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: I hear youre looking for Leon.  That makes me, his old-lady, and now you, looking for the little bastard. Leons gone, man. Vanished. You interested in his photographs?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: No shit... Well, Im afraid I cant help you.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I take it you dont know where he is, then?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Huh! You could always try Suicide Bridge.  You dont know Leon, do you?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I know his work better than I know him.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Let me put it this way then; the photographs and the man? One and the same, man, one and the same. At best fucking weird, at worst fucked-up fucking weird. Maybe you should think yourself lucky. Some folks just aint worth getting involved with. And Leon sure is one of em.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What about his girlfriend?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: What about which girlfriend?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Small, blond, good-looking. She was with him when we met. She had a funny English accent.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Oh. Thatd be Rhian, a Welsh chick he used to lay at weekends. She got wise and dumped him months ago...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Would you know where I might reach her?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Yeah! Somewhere in Wales. I dont really know her. Used to turn up in a Transit van on weekends, sell old furniture at Camden. Thats how come he only laid her at weekends, ha ha...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Could that be Camden Market?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Yeah. Why? Youre going to look for her... Shit! You really think his pictures are that good?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Fucked-up fucking weird.

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: Quest-ce que tu veux?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Un Autrichien. Negociant en pré- pubescents.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Whats an hour of your time worth these days, Nathalie?  Combien, Nathalie!

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: Cinq cents.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Viens.

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: Jai bien peur quil te faudra attendre.  Pas avant la matinée.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Tu sais où me trouver.

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: Bye. And thanks... Nathalie gently closes the door, eyes Lombard who shakes himself awake... rolls her eyes and surveys the room...

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: Où est passé ton salon?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Mon bureau coûtait trop cher.

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: Eh bien... Tes sûr que tas besoin de moi?  La petite ma lair assez bien foutue, non?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Alors?

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: Alors quoi?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Le montage, lemballage. Not your regular street muck, is it? This is collectors stuff. How much would it cost me?

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: A lachat, trois ou quatre mille. En location, cinq cent. Mais ça pourrait faire plus. Je ne sais pas. Cest pas vraiment mon truc.  I dont know any Austrian, Xavier.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: But maybe you know someone who does. An Austrian, in London, dealing in kids and snuff videos. How many can there be? These people supply to order. He has to be known, reachable.

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: Then why dont you reach him?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I dont have your credentials, Nathalie.

turns.speaker: NATHALIE
turns.text: We are so alike, Xavier. Still, sometimes I wonder which one of us is the ugliest.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: If you can, send me a receipt.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Okay, shitbag. Im only going to ask you this once. Where is Friedman?

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Who?  I dont know who the fuck youre talking about, sunshine.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Gluck.

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Figlio di puttana. Youre the French asshole who bumped off the London guys...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Five seconds. Then you die.

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Fuck...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Three...

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Glucks dead, you sonofabitch!

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Youre the lantern man, huh?  If you wanna see whats left of him...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The acid bath?

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Huh! Youve been around, eh?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Why did you kill Friedman?

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Let me give you a tip, asshole - no one pulls stunts like what you pulled in London and here tonight and hopes to get away with it. It upsets people. Its wrong. Fucking wrong.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Why did you kill him?

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Huh! You turned him into a liability, didnt you know?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Nice way to help a colleague in trouble.

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Thats just it. The sonofabitch didnt ask for help from his colleagues...  Testa di cazzo! Hiring some amateur outsiders to fix you... He hasnt gone to hell too soon... And neither will you, Mr Lamont!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Are you telling me Friedman didnt tell you I was here looking for him?

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: If he had, youd be dead.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: So why didnt he?

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: What do you think, huh?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I think youd rather not know what I think.

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Huh. Maybe he figured the news our London bureau got a visit from a hitman on behalf of a pissed off client wouldnt go down too well. He only shared his guilty secret last night. And then only cause he was so fucking edgy after calling his hotel we persuaded him to talk.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: So you killed him and went to clean out his hotel room... How did Friedman say he got to know where to find me?

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Thats the beauty. An anonymous call. Makes you wonder how many people know what youre up to, eh, French-fuck?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Try again, and this time be polite.

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: I can only tell you what he told us...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Not even scum like Friedman would go to the trouble of killing a stranger on the strength of one anonymous call.

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Some guy called to let him know the Frenchman whod called the night before he left London was in L.A. looking to kill him. He did his sums and decided to take the call seriously.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What sums?

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Two stiffs and a missing kid followed your visit to one of the London hotels. He didnt need your confession...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Youre sure he said his caller was a man?

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Thats what he said...

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: When they realise Im missing...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Shut up and walk...

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: What you gonna do? Kill me?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Dont tempt me. The last scumbag who thought I might kill him died soon afterwards.

turns.speaker: THE ITALIAN
turns.text: Huh. Im a businessman. What are you, eh?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Moreau? Cest moi. Alors...

turns.speaker: MOREAU
turns.text: Salut, Laurent. Ouais. It wasnt easy but I got what you wanted through Interpol. Say, whats your business with these Spitzes?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: They lost their son. Why?

turns.speaker: MOREAU
turns.text: It appears that in their younger days they were actively involved with a shady German group of Nazi hunters known as Never Forget. Over the years were talking about a dozen or so execution-type killings.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Are they still operative?

turns.speaker: MOREAU
turns.text: Their last suspected kill occurred two years back, though your Spitzes now probably do no more than bankroll the group. Still, Id watch my step. These people are well-connected, Laurent; former Israeli prime minister, etc. The ladys also president of an international Zionist organisation... Anyway, you get the picture.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Mossad?

turns.speaker: MOREAU
turns.text: Its a good guess...

turns.speaker: MAN ON DAIS
turns.text: Ha ha... Yes. With prices reaching an all time low, the name of the game has become have-it- where-its-at... As we all know, transportation has always been the costliest and trickiest part of this business...

turns.speaker: MAN WITH ITALIAN ACCENT
turns.text: Cost what?

turns.speaker: MAN ON DAIS
turns.text: Costliest!

turns.speaker: MAN WITH ITALIAN ACCENT
turns.text: Whats that? A word?

turns.speaker: MAN ON DAIS
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: MAN WITH ITALIAN ACCENT
turns.text: I dont know. Could be the sound of jewellery hitting a parquet floor, huh?

turns.speaker: MAN ON DAIS
turns.text: Very funny. Can I go on now?

turns.speaker: MAN WITH ITALIAN ACCENT
turns.text: Sure. But speak English, will ya, ha ha...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Oh dear, why is life so complicated? Sometimes I really wish I could be someone else.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: That's a good idea, sire.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Let someone else pretend to be you, and see if...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: ... if she can find me? -- That's a brilliant idea!  If she's really been sent by God she'll discover the trap, and if she's an assassin she'll kill the wrong man!  Bring her up!

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Why not you -- Jean d'Aulon?  The only man who's poorer than I am, and so the only man I can trust. Dignified, honorable, wise... what more could we ask of a king?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: My lord, I'm not sure that...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: My dear Aulon, to you it shall befall the honor of impersonating the royal blood!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Majesty, I can't...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Why, are you not ready to die for your king?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Of course I am, it's just that...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Good.  Until then, feel free to live like a king!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Sire, you know how bad I am at this sort of game.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: So... pretend it's not a game.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Jeanne, this is -- in fact -- my loyal friend and finest archer, Jean d'Aulon.  Jean... I place her in your care.  Find her suitable lodgings -- here -- in the castle... and guard her with your life.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Yes, my lord.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Here... to help pay Jeanne's ransom. All the Captains gave what they could, as well as the citizens of Orleans and the other towns she saved...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Very generous of you all.  How much?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: 10,000 gold crowns.

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: My dear Aulon...  That's fine...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne's been badly injured!  She jumped from the top of a tower into a frozen moat!

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: It's a miracle she's not dead!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: We have to do something before she tries it again!  I beg of you, my lord, don't let her down... let me organize an escape...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Jean, it's... it's not so easy...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: But not impossible... Gilles and La Hire are ready to risk everything to save her...

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Jean... me dear, loyal Jean... why do you want to oppose the will of God?  Jeanne wanted to go to Compiegne -- we let her -- she got caught.  Then, on my personal orders, Regnault proposed 30,000 crowns for her ransom, and once again the answer was no.  And now you say she tried to escape, and the answer is still no.  Jean, open your eyes -- can't you see the hand of God in all this?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: No.  I see the hand of Tremoille, and Regnault, and Yolande, and you... and they are dirty hands.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: What do you fear most now... my sword?  ... or his hands?

turns.speaker: CHARLES
turns.text: Tremoille... don't.  Please...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Listen, please accept my apologies for... you know, me pretending to be the... well it wasn't really my idea... well, yes it was my idea but...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Do you think I could have some water?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I would like some fresh straw.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Louis... water and fresh straw!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: And I would like to see a priest.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Now?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes.  I didn't confess today.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Right.  Raymond... a priest.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I shall also be needing a war horse -- mine is too slow -- and armor -- and a good sword -- and an artist to make me a banner.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Now?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Better today than tomorrow.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Well... uh -- this might take a little time -- but let me see what I can do.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I also need someone who can read and write.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: This I can do.  I was studying at the University of Paris -- till the English invaded it.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I thought you were an archer?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Yes, I am.  I'm an archer who can read and write.  Who do you want to write to?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: The King of England.  I want to give them the chance to leave Orleans in peace before I get there.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Who do they think I am?!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne, calm down.  You can't blame the people -- they've been hearing all about you for weeks.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: There's nothing to hear -- I haven't done anything.  And why haven't I done anything?  Because none of you will listen to me!!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne, stop it!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: How dare you stop me doing God's will!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: He didn't tell you to cut all your hair off...!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: How dare you tell me what God tells me to do!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Alright, whatever -- but since He's not going to come down and cut it himself, at least let someone cut it properly!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: What did they say?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Uh... they said... they will think about it.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: But... to be honest... I don't think they'll leave tomorrow.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: What's going on?!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: They've started the battle without me!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Not so... easily.  Why aren't you... fighting...?  go on... we're almost there...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne, you've been badly wounded...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No, it's... it's nothing, it's...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Alright... I promise to rest if you promise... to go back to the battle.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: I promise...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: The king said you're his finest archer...?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Come with me...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne, calm down, do you hear me? Are you alright?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: It's over, Jeanne.  We won, just as you said!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I'll go.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne, no...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne...!  Are you alright?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes.  Yes, I'm fine...  We need more brushwood!  Why are you staring at me like that?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Because there's an arrow in your leg.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne... the king has ordered us not to ride with you anymore.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: So... what am I supposed to do now?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: They've abandoned me... like everyone.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: What... what do you mean?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: It's been weeks since they spoke to me.  Since the coronation... no signs... nothing...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Maybe their silence is a sign...? Maybe it's a sign to go home?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: It's not time yet.  My mission is not over yet.  There is still more I must do before I can really -- finally -- go home.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: But how do you know that these -- these voices aren't really just -- well, you.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Well of course they're me!  That's how God talks to me.  If you listen hard enough, even you can hear him. Everyone can hear him.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: But I hear so many voices... one voice saying one thing, another voice saying the opposite -- love your enemy, kill your enemy -- what is good, what is evil...?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: All you have to do is stop talking and just listen.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: But how do you know what you hear is the truth?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I don't know it.  I feel it.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: You make it sound so simple...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: The truth is always simple... it's you, Jean, who's making things complicated.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Me?!  It's not me, it's God who makes everything complicated!  If he's all-powerful, why not let the English stay on their island in the first place?  And why let this war go on for a hundred years?  And why send you out to fight when a girl like you should be at home with your family?  Why, why?!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: So... even you don't believe in me anymore...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne... I believe in you... more than anyone...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: If you really want to help me, there's one thing you can do.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Tell me...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Tell the king to give me more men.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: That's not what I asked... Why do you want to marry me?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: You listen to your voices, I listen to my heart.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: What did the king say?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: He said that... he's making a treaty with the Duke of Burgundy and...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: It's a trap!  They're buying time till they can bring over more soldiers from England!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Did your voices tell you that?  You told me you hadn't heard them for months...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No, but...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Or maybe it's Jeanne who's in a trap -- her own trap -- a downward spiral that she can't stop?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Did you come back to marry me or to insult me?

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: To marry you.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I will ask my voices... if they come back one day.  Meanwhile... I'm going to Compiegne.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne... I have been hearing voices -- and believe me, those voices left me in no doubt that you must not go to Compiegne!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne... I believe in you -- but can you believe in me for once? Don't go... even if you don't want to marry me.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I would like to marry you.  But I have already promised myself... to God.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: But... you've done so much for God as it is... can't you do something for yourself for once -- for Jeanne?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: But it is what I want.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: To be killed in battle?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: If God wants me to win, he will find a way.  And if he wants me to die... if he wants me back... then that's fine too.  Then I'll be with him forever.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Will you at least let me stay with you?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: It would not be the same without you.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: We must sound the retreat!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Not yet!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Get back inside the town and see if the English are attacking from the other side!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: But... why... what's the point?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Do as I say!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: I want to stay with you...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: That's an order!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I am ready now...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Just give me a moment and then you'll be free...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I'm already free...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Yes yes... any moment... you're always so impatient...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: My gentle Captain... I'm staying.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: I -- I don't understand...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: One day you will.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: You don't know what you're saying. You're going to leave this place, Jeanne -- you're going home -- or whatever you want -- you're going to be happy, and have children, and...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: ... and maybe the king will give you some money, and a little land, and a title even...  ... wouldn't that be a fine thing? You, a lady of title!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I'm staying, Jean.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: No, you must come, Jeanne -- we need you -- so much has happened since you left... I have a new horse now, a white one, just like yours... and La Hire hardly swears at all anymore...  You can't stay -- they'll burn you!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I'm not afraid of the fire anymore. It will purify me...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne, you can't leave us like this!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: Jeanne's alive!

turns.speaker: DUNOIS
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: We have to press home the attack!

turns.speaker: DUNOIS
turns.text: Sound the retreat...

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: But I promised Jeanne we'd fight on!

turns.speaker: DUNOIS
turns.text: I made no such promise.  Sound the retreat for the night!

turns.speaker: AULON
turns.text: But that was her order!

turns.speaker: DUNOIS
turns.text: I'm fed up with taking her orders. She swore she'd defeat the English before nightfall, instead of which she goes and plays the fool and gets herself nearly killed!  Look at the mess we're in!  That's her mess, not mine...!  We're worse off then if she'd never come at all!  ... now do as I say and Sound the Retreat!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I won't tell you more about that. I'm more afraid of displeasing Him than not answering you...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: You're afraid of displeasing God when telling the truth?!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Did God forbid you to tell the truth?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No.  But my revelations were for the King of France, not for you.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Go onto the next question.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Good advice for the French, not for the English!  Do you think God hates the English?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I don't know, but you're all men of the church... why not ask Him yourself?

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Is it true that you launched an attack on Paris?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I tried to.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: It was on a Sunday, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I don't remember.  Maybe.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Do you think is was a good idea to launch an attack on a holy day?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: And didn't you order the citizens of Paris to surrender the city in the name of the King of Heaven?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No... I said "Surrender in the name of the King of France"...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: That is not what is written in the evidence... look for yourself!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I can't read.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Ah, yes, I forgot... God sent us an illiterate peasant to carry out such an important mission!  Do you think that God made the right decision, to take an ignorant girl to save the kingdom of France?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I leave the answer to God.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Do you have a sword?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Quite a few.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Didn't you also carry a banner?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Which did you prefer, your banner or your sword?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I was forty times more fond of my banner than my sword.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: And why was that?  Did it have some particular value or power?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No, it's just... a sword is a weapon.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: And so I... I prefer my banner.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: To avoid killing anyone.

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Are you saying that if you had not been carrying your banner you'd have killed more people?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No, of course not... I never killed anyone...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Then perhaps the temptation to kill would have been stronger... too strong perhaps...?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No!  I warned the English to go back home -- I begged them not to force us to fight -- they knew the defeat I would bring on them... why didn't they listen to me?

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: We have numerous witnesses who can confirm that you were not always carrying your banner...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes, probably... maybe...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: So sometimes you were carrying just your sword?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes, but...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: Did you use the sword that you held in your hand?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No, I... I held it up to...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: You held up your sword and flourished it about in the air? Like this?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes, maybe... I don't remember...

turns.speaker: BEAUPERE
turns.text: ... so you were in the middle of the battlefield, with your sword in your hand, waving it above your head... charging against the enemy, screaming and yelling... fighting for your life... and you want us to believe that in the middle of all this excitement you never killed anyone?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No, I... I never killed anyone!

turns.speaker: YOLANDE
turns.text: It is the sacred place that matters, Charles -- not the size.  Am I correct, Bishop?

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: Oh yes, my lady.  All true kings of France must first be anointed in our great cathedral of Rheims... with the holy oil of Clovis... for it was within these very walls that Saint Remy received the sacred oil from Heaven, brought to him by a white dove for the anointing of King Clovis...

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: I don't understand... the holy oil of Clovis... it was quite full the last time I saw it...

turns.speaker: YOLANDE
turns.text: And when was that?

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: Well... at the coronation of King Charles VI...

turns.speaker: YOLANDE
turns.text: Thirty years ago?  I'm not surprised it's gone...

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: No no, you don't understand -- this is no ordinary oil -- this is miraculous... this oil was brought from heaven by a white dove to crown King Clovis in this... very... cathedral...

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: W-w-what are you doing?!

turns.speaker: YOLANDE
turns.text: Performing a miracle.

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: Arrest them!

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: What are you doing?  This is an ecclesiastical court -- you have no right to do this!

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: Rouen is in English territory.  I have the right to do anything I like.  Take them away.

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: Who's running this trial, you or her?  I can't believe it!  This wretched girl -- how dare she speak to us like that?

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: She's loyal to her king... it's only to be expected that she...

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: I understand your impatience, but if you want this trial to be acknowledged as legal we must follow correct procedure and...

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: To hell with procedure!  We paid a bloody fortune for this slut, and we can do whatever the hell we like with her, whether the church likes it or not -- is that clear?

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: But if this trial seems fixed, I fear you'll have the very opposite result to the one you want...

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: We want her burned as a witch!

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: But in order to do so, the church must first prove her heresy, or else you'll be burning a martyr...

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: Well then?  Start proving... or else the church will have another martyr!

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Calm down, my lord, I beg you!

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: How can I calm down when I'm made the laughing-stock of the whole court?!  I've had enough!

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Be patient, my lord... you've seen how it is.  This girl has a way with people... but everyday we're making progress...

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: So long as this bitch remains alive, our armies refuse to fight!  Don't you understand?  They want proof that God is on their side... and the only way they're going to believe that is when they see her being burnt as a witch!

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: It is not for us to burn her, my lord.  That is your prerogative.

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: ... and your prerogative is to find her guilty...

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: But we can't do that unless she admits to blasphemy...

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: Well what are you waiting for? You've got a castle full of racks and ropes and pulleys:  go and torture the bitch!

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: You won't be able to drag anything from her that way.  You also must realize that many of my colleagues are... well, scared...

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: Scared of a girl?

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Scared to make a mistake.  Supposing she's right... supposing she really has been sent by God??

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: Whose side are you on, Cauchon?

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: I'm on the side of our Mother Holy Church.  Besides, a confession under torture will never convince anyone of her guilt.

turns.speaker: BUCK
turns.text: Well find some other way!  Be creative.  Tell them she fucks the devil... Hmm, not a bad idea... why can't you say that?  Sounds good to me... and who can prove she doesn't?

turns.speaker: BURGUNDY
turns.text: So... here is the famous Jeanne... Savior of Orleans... terror of the English?  You look pretty ordinary to me...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Am I... am I dead?

turns.speaker: BURGUNDY
turns.text: Dead you're worthless, darling.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Where... where am I?

turns.speaker: BURGUNDY
turns.text: Guess.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: My king will pay any ransom you ask.

turns.speaker: BURGUNDY
turns.text: Your king?  Ah yes, of course... What's he going to pay me with? Cows?  Chickens?  I prefer gold, and the English have plenty.  I wonder how much they'll pay... to have the Witch of Orleans in their clutches? Those English are so arrogant, they can't accept the idea of being defeated by a peasant girl... it has to have been the devil's work.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: God defeated the English, not me.

turns.speaker: BURGUNDY
turns.text: And God who allowed you to be caught?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Are you alright?  Did they hurt you?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No no, I'm fine, really...

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I was so worried -- we've all been looking for you!  The English are everywhere!  O thank you, lord!

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I was talking to the priest, and do you know what he said to me?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Quick -- hide in here...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: What about you?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Don't worry about me -- just stay in here... and don't move!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: But where are you going to be?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'll be right here... I promise.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Oh, thank you Lord!  I'm so glad to see you!  I need to confess... I haven't been confessed since Easter... or been to Mass... Will you hear me now?

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: I will hear you... but not now, not here.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Pierre Cauchon, Bishop of Beauvais. As you were captured in my diocese, the duty of conducting the trial falls upon me.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Trial?  What trial??

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Your trial, Jeanne.  On a charge of heresy.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: But... the King -- my king -- didn't he pay my ransom?

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: It seems that the English care more about you than the French.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: The English??

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Yes.  They paid your ransom... tomorrow you will be transferred to their great castle at Rouen.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Take the Holy Gospels in your hand and swear to tell the whole truth concerning everything you will be asked.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I don't know what you're going to ask me questions about.  You may ask things that I won't want to answer.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: You will swear to tell the truth about whatever you are asked.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I will willingly swear to tell the truth about earthly things, but as for my revelations, I've never told anyone except my king... Charles the Seventh... the one and only king of France.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: You must take the oath!  Not even a king, would refuse to take an oath to tell the truth in a matter of faith.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I will willingly swear to tell you what I am allowed to tell you, but as to the rest, even if you threaten to cut off my head, I still won't tell you.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: So... begin by telling us your name -- assuming you're allowed to tell us that much?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: My name is Jeanne.  My little cross I had round my neck was taken away from me.  I would like to have it back.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Show us a little more cooperation first.  Where were you born?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: In a village called Domremy.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: How old are you?

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Nineteen... or thereabouts...

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Were you baptized?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes.  In the church at Domremy.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Recite the Lord's Prayer.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Not unless you hear my confession.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Jeanne, listen to me very carefully. We are all men of faith, and we shall earnestly strive for the salvation of both your soul and body as though it were our own.  We do so in the name of our Holy Mother Church, who never closes her arms to those who would return to her.  But we cannot help you unless you submit to our learned judgment and authority.  Take heed of this charitable admonition, for if you persist in refusing our help, then we shall have no choice but to abandon you to the secular powers, and I think you know well enough the punishment that would await you.  So now... will you please recite Our Lord's Prayer?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Not unless you hear my confession.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Jeanne -- be careful -- you're not helping yourself by refusing to submit to our judgment...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: And you be careful, you who claim to be my judges, for you too will be judged one day...!

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Jeanne, you are not helping yourself.  If you don't answer our questions properly, your refusal will be taken into account.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: These questions have nothing to do with your trial.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: I assure you they do.  So... answer me... when was the last time you heard this voice?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Not long ago...

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: When exactly?  A day, a week -- when?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Last night.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: What were you doing when the voice came?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Praying.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: The voice was in your cell?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: What did it tell you?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Many things...

turns.speaker: CAUCHON
turns.text: Did it give you advice?  Good advice?
